chapter.title: Capabilities
chapter.para: The capabilities collection provides information about the supported capabilities of a Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager version. These capabilities include active features and available enumerated values for specific properties. An API user accesses this information through the rel="capabilities" link obtained from the entry point URI (see ).

section.title: Version-Dependent Capabilities
section.para: The capabilities element contains any number of version elements that describe capabilities dependent on a compatiblity level.
The version element includes attributes for major and minor version numbers. This indicates the current version level, which this document discusses in .
The following representation shows capabilities specific to Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager 3.0 and 2.2 respectively:
Each version contains a series of capabilities dependent on the version specified. This includes:

row.entry: Signifies if this version most recent supported compatibility level
The list of features the version supports.
List of supported fence agents and their configuration options.
Supported storage types for a version
List of all virtual machine types
Boot devices for a virtual machine
Available display protocols for a virtual machine
Network interface types for a virtual machine
List of interfaces for storage devices
Affinities for a host's placement policy
Environment variables for a virtual machine's custom scripts
List of available protocols for IP assignment
Options to determine virtual machine handling when a host in a cluster becomes non-operational
The format versions for storage meta-data

section.title: Current Version
section.para: The current element signifies if the version specified is the most recent supported compatibility level. The value is either a boolean true or false.

section.title: Features
section.para: Each version contains a list of compatible features.

row.entry: Defines the availablity of Transparent Hugepages for hosts

section.title: CPUs
section.para: Each cluster is configured with a minimal CPU type that all hosts in that cluster must support. Guests running on hosts within the cluster all run on this CPU type, ensuring that every guest is migratable to any host within the cluster.
Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization has a set of supported CPU types to choose from when configuring a cluster. Each CPU has the following properties:

row.entry: An opaque identifier for the CPU model
An indication as to the relative priority/preference for the CPUs in the list

section.screen: <capabilities> <version major="3" minor="0"> ... <cpus> <cpu id="Intel Xeon w/o XD/NX"> <level>2</level> </cpu> <cpu id="Intel Xeon"> <level>3</level> </cpu> ... </cpus> ... </version> </capabilities>

section.title: Power Managers
section.para: Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization platform provides a list of supported power_managers for host fencing configuration. Each power_management option contains the following properties:

row.entry: A list of options available to the supported fencing device. Options include a name and a value type.

section.screen: <capabilities> <version major="3" minor="0"> ... <power_managers> <power_management type="alom"> <options> <option type="bool" name="secure"/> <option type="int" name="port"/> </options> </power_management> <power_management type="apc"> <options> <option type="bool" name="secure"/> <option type="int" name="port"/> <option type="int" name="slot"/> </options> </power_management> <power_management type="bladecenter"> <options> <option type="bool" name="secure"/> <option type="int" name="port"/> <option type="int" name="slot"/> </options> </power_management> ... </power_managers> ... </version> </capabilities>

section.title: Fence Types
section.para: The fence_types element defines fence_type options to fence a host and reduce power usage.

section.title: Storage Types
section.para: The storage_types element defines the available physical storage_type options.

section.title: Storage Domain Types
section.para: The storage_domain_types element shows the available storage_domain_type options a user creates in a virtualization environment.

section.title: Virtual Machine Types
section.para: The vm_types element defines each virtual machine type (vm_type) available for creation in a virtual environment.

section.title: Boot Devices
section.para: Each virtual machine boots from a selected device. The boot_devices element lists such boot_device options.

section.title: Display Types
section.para: Access to a virtual machine through Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager requires a display protocol. The display_types element lists each display_type protocol.

section.title: NIC Types
section.para: A virtual machine requires a network interface to connect to a network. The nic_types element defines the supported NIC types available. Each nic_type depends on the drivers available for different types of virtual machines. VirtIO drivers are available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4.8 and above, and for Windows virtual machines. Windows supports rtl8139 without the need for drivers. Other Linux machines, or earlier versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, use e1000 or rtl8139.

section.title: Disk Types
section.para: Each virtual machine requires a virtual disk for storage. The disk_types element lists the available virtual disk_type options.

section.title: OS Types
section.para: Each virtual machine contains an os_type value to define the virtual machine operating system. The default is unassigned.

section.title: Disk Formats
section.para: An API user selects the format for virtual disks. The disk_formats element defines the format types. The disk_format types include pre-allocated (raw) or thin-provisioned (Copy-On-Write or cow).

section.title: Disk Interfaces
section.para: The disk_interfaces element lists disk_interface options for emulated protocols to interface with virtual disks.

section.title: Virtual Machine Affinities
section.para: Virtual machines migrate between hosts in a cluster. The vm_affinities element defines each available migration affinity for virtual machines.

section.title: Custom Properties
section.para: The custom_properties element lists a set of environment variables for a virtual environment. The virtual environment uses these variables as parameters for event-triggered VDSM scripts. Each custom_property includes attributes for a property name and a regular expression (regexp) to define the format of the property value.
section.screen: <capabilities> <version major="3" minor="0"> ... <custom_properties> <custom_property name="sap_agent" regexp="^(true|false)$"/> <custom_property name="sndbuf" regexp="^[0-9]+$"/> <custom_property name="vhost" regexp="^(([a-zA-Z0-9_]*):(true|false))(,(([a-zA-Z0-9_]*):(true|false)))*$"/> <custom_property name="viodiskcache" regexp="^(none|writeback|writethrough)$"/> </custom_properties> ... </version> </capabilities>

section.title: Boot Protocols
section.para: The boot_protocol element lists each possible IP assignment boot_protocol for hosts when booting.

section.title: Error Handling
section.para: A Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager determines whether to migrate virtual machines on a non-operational host using one of the on_error options the in the error_handling element.

section.title: Storage Formats
section.para: The storage_formats element lists the available format versions for storage meta-data.

section.title: Permits
section.para: Permits are allowable actions a user assigns to a role. Each permit contains:

row.entry: The opaque identifier for a permit
The permit is assigned to only administrative roles

section.title: Scheduling Policies
section.para: The scheduling_policies element defines the load-balancing and power sharing modes for hosts in the cluster.
